body: Have you run Windows Update on that production server? This was a bug in the .NET Framework fixed (see http://help.octopusdeploy.com/discussions/problems/8154-could-not-load-file-or-assmebly-systemcore-after-updating-to-1611718 as an example)

Jimmy,

Before posting this issue we tried to install the patch to the .NET
Framework 4 but it did not work on our server. It said it did not apply. We
tried x86 and 64 bits installer versions.

This is a server I have no control so I really don't know if they keep it
updated.

Just curious: why does AutoMapper reference system.core 2.0.5.0? Is it for
backward compatibility or something else?

Thanks for the awesome library!

On Saturday, September 7, 2013, Jimmy Bogard wrote:

> Have you run Windows Update on that production server? This was a bug in
> the .NET Framework fixed (see
> http://help.octopusdeploy.com/discussions/problems/8154-could-not-load-file-or-assmebly-systemcore-after-updating-to-1611718as an example)

What's weird is that I don't see that it does - I see it referencing
System.Core v4.0.0.0. I don't know where that 2.0.5.0 version comes from :\

I have the same issue and i can't resolve it. I have a server with iis6 and .net 4.0. 

Could not load file or assembly 'System.Core, Version=2.0.5.0, Culture=neutral,PublicKeyToken=7cec85d7bea7798e, Retargetable=Yes' or one of its dependencies. 
The given assembly name or codebase was invalid. (Exception from HRESULT: 0x80131047)  
at MySolution.Web.AutoMapperConfiguration.Configure() 
at MySolution.Web.MvcApplication.Application_Start()
How did you solve it?

Do you have any info on what versions of .NET are on that production server?

On Sun, Sep 8, 2013 at 11:23 PM, Miguel Salazar notifications@github.comwrote:

> @leniel https://github.com/leniel : Thanks a lot!
> 
> It's some complex try with the patch of .net. I don't have control of
> production server. =/
> 
> I revert back to 2.2.1 version and now works. For now it's ok.
> 
> —
> Reply to this email directly or view it on GitHubhttps://github.com/AutoMapper/AutoMapper/issues/383#issuecomment-24039459
> .

FWIW I'm getting the exact same issue, but with Mono & Xamarin Studio.  

The weird thing for me is, I get a build error when I call " MapperRegistry.AllMappers".  The build error status that the type returned from Func[IEnumerable[IObjectMapper]] requires the reference to System.Core 2.0.5.  If I remove the reference to MapperRegistry.AllMappers, it builds and works (at least to some level).

issue.title: Nuget problems
issue.body:
Current version of AutoMapperAssist on Nuget requires AutoMapper >=v2.0 - but fails to run with AutoMapper v3.0 (the current version).
Also, AutoMapperAssist can no longer be installed with the new version of Nuget (that ships with VS2012.4 RC2) - installation fails with:
Install failed. Rolling back...
Authors is required.

body: @jbogard Yes. The app is running over version 4.0.30319. Only the app in virtual directory. The website is running over v2.0.50727 (IIS6 - Win server 2003 R2) If my memory serves me correctly, this is the installer of v4.0.30319: http://www.microsoft.com/en-us/download/details.aspx?id=17718
DID NOT MEAN TO CLOSE WITH THAT COMMENT. Can you try the latest NuGet version?
I will try the latest nuget version asap.  First have to figure out how to nuget the bleeding-edge gems in xamarin, it seems stuck on 3.0.  Will let you know.

Probably because the latest drop is prerelease, I'm guessing?

On Mon, Sep 16, 2013 at 8:59 AM, Darren Cauthon notifications@github.comwrote:

> I will try the latest nuget version asap. First have to figure out how to
> nuget the bleeding-edge gems in xamarin, it seems stuck on 3.0. Will let
> you know.
> 
> —
> Reply to this email directly or view it on GitHubhttps://github.com/AutoMapper/AutoMapper/issues/383#issuecomment-24511506
> .
Yup.  I'm sure there's a toggle around this, I'll figure it out. :)
I experience this issue too but on .NET framework 4.5, the issue persists in latest stable and pre-release builds on nuget, I too had to revert to 2.2.1

I believe this is related to me (accidentally) releasing AutoMapper non-strong-named. The latest drop on NuGet includes strong-named assemblies and fixed PCL bindings. I do wish I could reproduce this one, but I did get a similar sort of issue with another codebase. Can you give it a try?

Sorry to report but still the same issue in latest pre-release build on NuGet.

we've had similar issues in the past, it was related to using the Async/Await pack for .NET 4.0, we could workaround it then by binding redirections iirc. Ever since 4.5 we've never ran into this issue again though.

WHAT'S AFTER STEP 3

And what's "cuttingEdge.Conditions"? Your own library?

On Thu, Oct 17, 2013 at 5:03 PM, Colin Bowern notifications@github.comwrote:

> We're seeing something similar. I'm wondering if the PCL piece has a bug
> in it because I'm able to repro with the following in VS 2012:
> 1. Create a new .NET 4.5 class library
> 2. Add in the AutoMapper (latest release or pre-release) and
>    CuttingEdge.Conditions (can really be any library without PCL hooks by the
>    looks of it)
> 3. Crea
> 
> —
> Reply to this email directly or view it on GitHubhttps://github.com/AutoMapper/AutoMapper/issues/383#issuecomment-26556979
> .

The web version was updated while the email notification caught my accidental post hotkey. The complete post is on the Github site. At this point I suspect this is a PCL / CLR issue not as much an AutoMapper issue directly.

Sent from my Windows Phone
